I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of India (Government) has undertaken several initiatives to encourage 
sustainable urban development in the country, including the recent declaration of a national 
incentive-linked fund, the Jawaharlal Nehru National Urban Renewal Mission (JNNURM). The 
JNNURM  is  expected  to  invest  approximately  $11  billion  equivalent  for  urban  infrastructure 
development in 63 of the largest cities in India. The Ministry of Urban Development (MUD) has 
been designated as Executing Agency (EA) for the infrastructure and governance component of 
the  JNNURM.1 The  Government  requested  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  provide 
technical  assistance  (TA)  to  the  MUD  Mission  Directorate  to  successfully  implement  the 
JNNURM.2  
 
2.  The ADB Mission visited India on 6–13 December to discuss with the Government the 
proposed TA. The Mission met with MUD and the Department of Economic Affairs, and also held 
a workshop with senior MUD officials to develop the scope, implementation arrangements, terms 
of reference for consulting services, and financing arrangements of the TA. The project design 
and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  According to India’s 2001 population census, more than 285 million people (27.8% of the 
total population) live in urban areas. With this large base, which is growing at the rate of around 
2.7% annually, India has the world’s second largest urban population. Given the current trends in 
population growth and migration, India’s urban population is estimated to reach 575 million by 
2030.3 The importance of India’s urban sector is indisputable. The urban sector contribution to 
India’s net domestic product is estimated to be 50–52%. In India, 64.7%  of employment in trade, 
commerce, and financial services; 65% in manufacturing; and 68% in the transport sector are 
concentrated in urban areas.4  
 
4.  Despite the significance of India’s urban sector, however, India’s cities are characterized 
by widespread poverty, inadequate urban infrastructure, and environmental degradation. The 
2001 population census found that although 91% of India’s urban dwellers had access to drinking 
water,  only 49.7% of households had tap water on their premises. Similarly, only 57.4% of urban 
households had sanitation facilities on their premises. It must be noted that existence of the 
service does not imply its adequacy or quality, so the effective situation may be worse. Slums, 
another highly visible manifestation of urban poverty, housed approximately 40 million people, 
representing around 14.12% of the total urban population in India in 2001. Urban poverty in urban 
areas  has  declined  from  52%  in  1972–1973  to  23.6%  in  1999–2000,  but  this  percentage 
represents  65  million  people  who  live  in  absolute  poverty.5 Poor  urban  development  and 
management is not only undermining India’s ability to deliver quality of life to its citizens, but also 
constraining potential local and national economic growth. The need for a strong focus and 
accelerated investment in urban development is clear. 
                                                 
1  MUD, Government of India, has been designated as Executing Agency (EA) for the “infrastructure and governance” 
subcomponent under the JNNURM, and the Ministry of Urban Employment and Poverty Alleviation has been 
designated EA for the “basic services to the poor” subcomponent. Both ministries will be setting up their own mission 
directorates.  
2  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 3 January 2006.

5.  In recognition of the critical importance of rapid urban development, India’s Prime Minister 
launched the JNNURM on 3 December 2005.6 The JNNURM is a “reforms driven, fast track, 
planned development of identified cities with focus on efficiency in urban infrastructure/services 
delivery  mechanism,  community  participation  and  accountability  of  Urban  Local 
Bodies/Parastatals towards citizens.”7 The JNNURM will be for 7 years, starting in 2005–2006, 
and includes a central outlay of approximately $11 billion.8 Sixty-three cities are designated as 
eligible  for  investments  through  the  JNNURM.  Each  city  will  enter  into  a  memorandum  of 
agreement (MOA) with the Government and the parent state and commit itself to a range of 
mandatory and optional reforms related to urban governance. City development plans (CDPs) will 
be developed. They will consider each city’s unique needs in an integrated and participatory 
manner, and prioritize investments that need to be made during the JNNURM period and beyond. 
From the prioritization in the CDPs, the cities will prepare detailed project reports (DPRs) for 
investments seeking JNNURM funding. Funding for physical improvements will be based on an 
appraisal  of  the  DPRs.  Five  percent  of  the  overall  JNNURM  funding  will  finance  consulting 
services and technical assistance to urban local bodies (ULBs) and state governments to prepare 
their CDPs and DPRs. The JNNURM will finance, on a grant basis, between 35% and 90% of the 
costs associated with urban infrastructure investments, depending on the classification of the 
city.9 Part  of  the  remaining  financing  will  be  provided  through  state  governments,  and  the 
remainder is expected to be financed through external funding agencies, the private sector, and 
India’s capital market.  
 
6.  MUD has been designated as the ministry to launch the JNNURM; it will also be the EA for 
the infrastructure and governance subcomponent under the JNNURM. The Ministry of Urban 
Employment and Poverty Alleviation has been designated as EA for the basic services to the poor 
subcomponent. The Government of India is in the process of establishing a Mission Directorate 
within MUD to spearhead all efforts under the infrastructure and governance component of the 
JNNURM.  
 
7.  While significant staff are being assigned to the Mission Directorate,10 their capacity to 
independently manage and implement the complex array of tasks associated with the JNNURM, 
especially in the initial stages where many of the technical details and procedures need to be 
refined,  is of  concern.  Guidelines  for  developing  and  appraising  CDPs  and  DPRs,  although 
outlined, need significant refinement to ensure that JNNURM resources are allocated efficiently 
and transparently. Systems to track JNNURM funding commitments and expected project cash 
flows, and monitor individual project indicators and overall JNNURM performance need to be put 
in place. Significant support is also needed to enable MUD to effectively guide state and city 
governments through the process of defining individual reform agendas; preparing CDPs, DPRs, 
and other reports necessary to access JNNURM funds; attracting private sector participation in 
the development efforts; and setting up means to transparently account for and monitor individual 
project investments among others. The proposed TA is designed to provide MUD with the support 
it needs to ensure effective ramping up and implementation of the JNNURM, and transfer of 
knowledge to MUD staff for efficient management of the JNNURM.

III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The proposed TA will provide technical assistance to the MUD Mission Directorate for 
effective implementation of the JNNURM and technical support to ULBs for accessing JNNURM 
funds. The underlying goal of the TA is to leverage and mobilize the substantial resources 
allocated by the Government for urban development through the JNNURM, and to help ensure 
maximum impact of the program in terms of reforms at the state and local level,11 as well as in 
terms of physical development of urban infrastructure. As such, the primary impact of the TA will 
be  the  effective  management  and  disbursement  of  JNNURM  funds,  significant  governance 
reforms at the state and ULB levels, efficient processing and implementation of JNNURM-funded 
interventions at the ULB level, and overall improvement in the urban environment of India’s major 
cities.  
 
9.  The specific outcomes of the TA will be (i) a well-staffed project cell set up within MUD to 
help ramp up and implement the JNNURM effectively and efficiently; (ii) significantly enhanced 
capacity of MUD to evaluate and appraise CDPs, DPRs, and related policy reforms; (iii) enhanced 
capacity within MUD to provide technical and advisory support to state and ULB governments in 
implementing and managing integrated urban development and governance reform programs 
funded  through  the  JNNURM;  (iv)  increased  awareness  at  state  and  ULB  levels  about  the 
resources  available  through  the  JNNURM  and  the  procedures  to  access  such  funds;  (v) 
significantly  enhanced  reach  and  effectiveness  of  the  JNNURM  through  close  monitoring  of 
overall performance and technical support to ULB and state governments in implementing reforms 
and project interventions; (vi) decreased urban poverty due to improved urban infrastructure and 
access to basic services in India’s largest cities; and (vii) a significant increase in private sector 
participation in urban infrastructure development and management throughout India.   
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will primarily comprise consulting support to enable MUD to effectively manage 
and implement the JNNURM, and maximize its policy reform and urban development impacts. 
The consulting team will form part of the project cell within the JNNURM Project Directorate at 
MUD, which will spearhead JNNURM implementation. Consulting inputs at the early stages of the 
TA will help MUD refine the guidelines and processes for project preparation, appraisal, and 
evaluation; and assist city and state governments in meeting such requirements. The TA will also 
assist MUD in setting up systems and procedures to monitor the progress of project, city, or state 
investments individually, and of the JNNURM as a whole. The consulting team will work closely 
with  MUD  staff  assigned  to  the  JNNURM.  Significant  transfer  of  expertise  in  financial 
management, project management, monitoring, and implementation to MUD over the TA period is 
expected.  Key activities under the TA will include the following: 
(i)  Support the setup of the JNNURM project cell within the Project Directorate of MUD 
and assist MUD in the overall management and implementation of the JNNURM. 
(ii)  Assist  MUD  in  promoting  the  JNNURM  at  the  state  and  local  levels,  refine  the 
requirements and guidelines for accessing funds, and provide close support to state 
                                                 
11 A memorandum of agreement between each of the ULBs, states, and JNNURM will outline a series of required and 
optional reforms aimed at greater transparency and efficiency, and creating an enabling regulatory environment for 
private sector investment. The TA will support states/ULBs in defining their individual reform agendas, in managing 
associated change processes, and in monitoring performance.

and city governments at all stages in the process to ensure efficient disbursements 
and smooth implementation. 
(iii)  Conduct a baseline survey of the infrastructure and regulatory environments in ULBs 
slated for JNNURM investment, assist states and cities to define their reform agendas 
and to enter into MOAs with the Government, and monitor their progress over time. 
(iv)  Refine guidelines for preparing and appraising CDPs and DPRs, advise city and/or 
state governments on CDP and DPR preparation requirements/methods, and build 
MUD capacity to check compliance, ensure quality, and evaluate the appraisals of 
CDPs and DPRs.  
(v)  Monitor the progress of project and governance reform interventions funded through 
the  JNNURM,  conduct  physical  and  financial  audits  of  projects  to  ensure  full 
accountability, and assist state and city governments to resolve any issues in project 
implementation. 
(vi)  Create  a  management  information  system  (MIS)  that  will  allow  city  and  state 
governments  to  update  project  indicators  on-line  and  allow  MUD  to  track  overall 
performance of the JNNURM, forecast funding requirements, and monitor individual 
project performance efficiently. 
(vii)  Advise the cities in accessing other funds to supplement JNNURM grants, and ensure 
that  the  JNNURM  catalyses  greater  investment  in  urban  infrastructure  from  other 
sources—especially the private sector.  
 
11.  Further details on the expertise to be provided through the TA and the specific tasks to be 
carried out are included in the outline terms of reference for consulting services.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The total cost of 
the TA is $2.5 million equivalent, comprising foreign exchange of $.005 million and local currency 
equivalent of $2.495 million. The entire foreign exchange cost and $1.995 million in local currency 
equivalent  will  be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  ADB.  The  Government  will  contribute  the 
remaining  local  currency  equivalent  of  $0.5  million  for  counterpart  staff  support,  office 
accommodation, facilities for meetings and workshops, and other administrative expenses. The 
Government will also provide all information and logistical support required for the TA activities. 
The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  MUD will be the EA and will be responsible for overall coordination of all TA activities. The 
consultants will report directly to the designated mission director of the JNNURM who will be 
appointed by MUD. The Government will appoint counterpart staff12 to be part of the JNNURM 
project cell, who will work directly with the TA consultants. The TA will be implemented over 3 
years beginning about March 2006. 
  
                                                 
12  Counterpart staff will include a mission director, three coordinators, three directors, two deputy secretaries, three 
undersecretaries, four section officers, four data entry officers, and three accounts officers.

5
14.  Consulting services will total 310 person-months of inputs, all to be provided by domestic 
consultants.13 The core consulting team will comprise a management specialist (team leader), a 
municipal finance specialist, municipal engineer, and an urban planner for 36 person-months each. 
Other consultants that will provide intermittent inputs over the project duration will include a 
project monitoring and evaluation specialist, financial analyst, and a governance and change 
management specialist for 24 person-months each; a project implementation specialist, legal and 
regulatory specialist, and urban renewal specialist for 18 person-months each; an economist and 
a transportation planner for 12 person-months each; and a social development specialist and 
environment specialist for 8 person-months each. A consulting firm will be engaged using the 
quality- and cost-based selection method and a simplified technical proposal, in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the 
selection and engagement of domestic consultants. The outline terms of reference for consulting 
services is in Appendix 3. 
 
15.  The consultants will produce an inception report within 30 days of TA commencement. 
The report will include a detailed work plan and implementation strategy for all TA activities. The 
inception report and work plan will be developed in close collaboration with MUD, and will also 
indicate a projected schedule of all workshops and training sessions to be conducted through the 
TA. Brief quarterly reports will be submitted, summarizing progress of the TA and the JNNURM, 
highlighting any issues to be addressed. More detailed annual reports will document overall 
performance of the TA and the JNNURM, milestones achieved, and constraints faced. A final 
report due at the end of the TA will document the overall impacts achieved through the JNNURM 
and the effectiveness of the TA. During implementation, other reports or documents may be 
prepared by the consultants, as required, based on the needs of MUD or ADB.  
 
16.  The  Government  will  provide  office  space,  furniture,  logistical  and  all  administrative 
support necessary to coordinate TA activities with state and city governments, as well as with 
other government agencies as required. Office equipment and materials to be financed by the TA 
will be procured by the consultants in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for Procurement or other 
procedures acceptable to ADB. Upon completion of the TA, the procured equipment will become 
the property of MUD.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
17.  The President recommends that the Board approve the provision of technical assistance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $2,000,000 on a grant basis to the Government of India for 
Support for the Jawaharlal Nehru National Urban Renewal Mission Project.  
                                                 
13  Qualified domestic consultants with required expertise are available in India for efficient and cost effective delivery of 
the consulting services under the TA.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Consulting services will total 310 person-months of inputs, all to be provided by domestic 
consultants. A consulting firm will provide the full package of support using the quality- and cost-
based selection method, in accordance with Asian Development Bank's (ADB) Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants  and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for selecting and engaging 
domestic consultants. A simplified technical proposal will be used. 
 
2.  The outline terms of reference for each consultant in this document are not exhaustive, and 
may  be  supplemented  and  expanded  as  required  to  meet  Government  of  India  and  ADB 
requirements.  
 
A.  Management Expert/Team Leader (36 person-months) 
 
3.  The team leader will be a management expert, with a strong background in finance and 
general management. The consultant (i) will have an advanced degree in management/finance 
and at least 10 years experience and proven track record at a senior general management level in 
the private sector; (ii) should have demonstrated experience in large-scale investment decision 
making, interaction with India’s capital market, managing large interdisciplinary teams, preparing 
and managing budgets, and managing and improving overall performance of an organizational unit; 
and (iii) should be intimately familiar with the Indian business environment, and the full range of 
issues  associated  with  urban  infrastructure  development,  finance,  and  the  interface  between 
government and external funding agencies. Additional background in engineering, urban planning, 
or policy will be an advantage. The consultant will do the following: 
 
(i)  Report directly to the joint secretary, Ministry of Urban Development (MUD) and the 
mission director of the Project Directorate.  
(ii)  Be responsible for the overall management of the consulting team and budget, and for 
the timely and efficient delivery of all project outputs. 
(iii)  Ensure effective mobilization and full utilization of all consulting inputs. 
(iv)  Closely monitor the performance of all aspects of the project cell, in close collaboration 
with the MUD leadership, and allocate resources and consultant support as required to 
ensure that requirements of national, state, and urban local bodies (ULB) governments 
requirements  related  to  the  Jawaharlal  Nehru  National  Urban  Renewal  Mission 
(JNNURM) are fully addressed.  
(v)  Direct a study assessing the existing status of reforms in all JNNURM cities and states, 
including the capacity to undertake reforms. 
(vi)  Develop a set of benchmarks/indicators against which progress of the JNNURM can be 
measured, especially with respect to project management and implementation, and 
outcomes of city development plans (CDPs) and detailed project reports (DPRs). 
(vii)  Make one-to-one visits to JNNURM cities for assessment of their intention, ability, and 
capacity to access the JNNURM, as well as initial sensitization the JNNURM. 
(viii)  Provide  knowledge  support—including  presentation  of  regional  best  practices—for 
initiating  CDPs  on  a  demand  basis,  specially  to  northeast  and  other  economically 
backward states.  
(ix)  Undertake  at  the  state  capital  workshops  on  implementation  of  mandatory  and 
obligatory reforms for state and cities. The focus will be on identifying road maps for 
implementing mandatory and obligatory reforms. 
(x)  Provide  wherever  called  for,  hand-holding  support  to  states,  for  developing 
memorandum of agreements (MOAs). 
(xi)  Lead the technical support group at the project cell, which will provide support to cities 
and states on demand basis.

12  Appendix 3 
 
(xii)  Support the Mission Directorate in refining guidelines and timelines for the JNNURM as 
required.  
(xiii)  Assist the Mission Directorate in developing a consolidated fund flow for the JNNURM. 
(xiv)  Provide  other  necessary  support  to  the  Mission  Directorate  including  making 
presentations to the national steering group.  
 
B.  Municipal Finance Specialist (36 person-months) 
  
4.  The specialist will have a graduate degree in business or finance, and extensive experience 
and training in municipal finance, project finance, resource mobilization, public-private partnerships, 
and urban infrastructure investment. Experience in evaluating and financing urban infrastructure 
investments from a private sector view will be an advantage. The primary responsibility is to 
explore  and  advise  MUD,  as  well  as  state  and  city  governments,  on  all  possible  financing 
modalities for projects proposed for JNNURM financing. Specifically, the specialist will do the 
following: 
 
(i)  Review, assess, and maintain an inventory of all sources of municipal finance of all 
JNNURM cities and assist in identifying avenues for leveraging funds for infrastructure. 
(ii)  Wherever called for, assist city governments in developing road maps for implementing 
reforms for improved revenue mobilization, with focus on property tax, user charges, 
accessing central funds, accessing market-based funds, debt swaps, etc. 
(iii)  Explore  alternate  long-term  municipal  finance  options  available  for  financing  urban 
infrastructure in cities and leveraging the JNNURM funds. 
(iv)  Review the current financial status of JNNURM cities and suggest measures for making 
them more creditworthy during the appraisal and implementation of the JNNURM. 
(v)  Maintain active dialog with potential sources of financing and encourage broad-based 
support for the JNNURM. 
(vi)  Support the team leader in making one-to-one visits to JNNURM cities for assessing 
their intention, ability, and capacity to access JNNURM, as well as initial sensitization to 
the JNNURM. 
(vii)  Support the team leader in assessing existing status of reforms in all JNNURM cities 
and states, including their capacity to undertake reforms. 
(viii)  Assess CDPs and DPRs specifically with respect to identified areas of local government 
financing and, if required, help city governments identify and secure additional sources 
of funds for proposed infrastructure investments. 
(ix)  Serve as a core member of the technical support group at the project cell, and provide 
support to cities and states as required.  
(x)  Advise MUD as well as state and city governments on innovative ways to structure 
financing and reforms related to select infrastructure investments so as to minimize 
costs, maximize efficiency of implementation, enable private sector participation, and 
ensure financial sustainability. 
 
C.  Municipal Engineer (36 person-months) 
 
5.  The engineer will (i) have a broad range of experience in urban infrastructure and a strong 
background in public health engineering, especially water supply and sanitation;(ii) have at least 7 
years experience in designing and managing municipal infrastructure projects, preferably projects 
funded by aid agencies; and  (iii) be very familiar with the laws and procedures of the Indian 
municipal environment. Experience as municipal engineer across a number of states will be an 
advantage. Specifically, the consultant will do the following: 
 
(i)  Assist  in  ensuring  quality  and  monitoring  compliance  of  DPRs,  and  project 
implementation.

Appendix 3  13
(ii)  Wherever called for, provide city governments with technical guidance on project 
formulation and support city governments with implementing DPRs.  
(iii)  Support the team leader in making one-to-one visits to JNNURM cities for assessing 
their intention, ability, and capacity to access the JNNURM, as well as for initial 
sensitization to the JNNURM. 
(iv)  Ensure adequate provision for operation and maintenance, value for money urban 
infrastructure creation, and overall sustainability. 
(v)  As a core member of the technical support group at the project cell, provide support 
to cities and states as required.  
(vi)  Support  the  team  leader  in  undertaking  workshops  at  the  state  capital  on 
implementation of mandatory and obligatory reforms for state and cities. The focus 
will be on identifying road maps for implementing mandatory and obligatory reforms. 
(vii)  Assist the team leader and the monitoring and evaluation expert in developing 
municipal  infrastructure-related  benchmarks/indicators  against  which  progress  of 
DPR implementation can be measured.  
 
D.  Urban Planner (36 person-months) 
 
6.  The consultant should have a graduate degree in urban planning with at least 6 years of 
experience in urban planning in developing countries. Experience with developing city strategies, 
development plans, land use and zoning, master planning, and integrated urban infrastructure 
development is required. Experience in housing and real estate development, water supply and 
sanitation, and other urban services will be an advantage. The consultant is primarily responsible 
for quality assurance of CDPs, and for ensuring that all project investments are considered and 
evaluated  in  the  context  of  the  broader  planning  requirements  of  each  city.  Specifically,  the 
consultant will do the following: 
 
(i)  Evaluate, assure quality, and check all CDPs and DPRs to ensure full compliance with 
all JNNURM planning requirements, as well as other prevailing state and city planning 
documents. 
(ii)  Assist  the  team  leader  in  developing  guidelines  for  preparing,  appraising,  and 
evaluating CDPs.  
(iii)  Provide  technical  support  to  state  and  city  governments  to  ensure  that  CDPs  are 
developed  in  a  comprehensive  and  meaningful  manner,  and  meet  all  JNNURM 
requirements. 
(iv)  Wherever  called  for,  provide  technical  support  to  state  and  city  governments,  in 
implementing mandatory and obligatory reforms including those related to land tenure, 
building bylaws, water conservation, streamlining the approval process for construction, 
provision of basic services to the urban poor, earmarking of developed land in housing 
projects for the poor, etc.  
(v)  Support the team leader in undertaking workshops on implementation of mandatory and 
obligatory  reforms  for  state  and  cities  at  the  state  capital.  The  focus  will  be  on 
identifying road maps for implementing mandatory and obligatory reforms. 
(vi)  Provide other necessary support as identified by the team leader. 
 
E.  Project Monitoring and Evaluation Specialist (24 person-months) 
 
7.  The specialist will have a management background and at least 7 years experience in 
monitoring  and  evaluating  large  projects  and  programs,  preferably  in  the  urban  sector.  The 
specialist will be responsible for monitoring the overall performance of the JNNURM, progress on 
the reform agenda of state governments and ULBs, and of project interventions funded through the 
JNNURM. The specialist will work closely with the team leader and other sector experts to ensure 
that any issues or problems in implementing the JNNURM are identified early, and that adequate

14  Appendix 3 
 
financial and staff and/or consultant resources are mobilized to address any concerns. Specifically, 
the specialist will do the following: 
 
(i)  Develop  a  methodology  and  format  for  collecting  and  tracking  data  on  JNNURM 
progress. 
(ii)  Assist  the  team  leader  in  developing  benchmarks  and/or  indicators  against  which 
progress of the JNNURM can be measured.  
(iii)  Conduct a baseline survey to assess the conditions of important reforms at each level 
of government, as well as the status of the full-range basic services and systems 
expected to be covered through the JNNURM in the 63 eligible cities and states.  
(iv)  Develop  a  database  at  the  central  level  and  a  method  for  on-line  data  entry  for 
continuous tracking of JNNURM progress in each state and city. In collaboration with 
the team leader, outsource (as a lump sum contract) the development and management 
of this platform to a domestic information technology firm, but be responsible for its 
effectiveness and comprehensiveness. The database system to be used should be an 
off-the-shelf database software that will require minimal customization and training. City 
and state governments must have the ability to update implementation data remotely 
via the internet. 
(v)  Ensure that each city updates monitoring data regularly, and train and support ULBs 
and state governments to meet this requirement. 
(vi)  Submit  aggregate  quarterly  reports  to  the  Mission  Directorate  on  the  progress  of 
reforms, financial disbursements, and other relevant indicators. 
(vii)  If  required,  provide  technical  support  to  the  Mission  Directorate  for  evaluating  the 
benefits of JNNURM interventions. 
(viii)  Work  with MUD,  the  team  leader,  and  other  experts  to  ensure  that  any  concerns 
identified are promptly addressed.  
 
F.  Financial Analyst (24 person-months) 
 
8.  The analyst will have a university degree in finance, accounting, or business, and at least 5 
years experience in financial management, as well as in financial and economic analyses of large-
scale infrastructure-type projects. The analyst will have primary responsibility for tracking all MUD 
expenditures, disbursements, and other financial activity associated with the JNNURM, and for 
providing regular updates to the team leader and MUD. The analyst will also be responsible for 
quality  assurance  and  checking  compliance  of  DPRs  to  ensure  least-cost  interventions,  and 
financial and/or economic viability of all JNNURM investments. Specifically, the analyst will do the 
following: 
 
(i)  Work with the project monitoring and evaluation specialist to ensure that all important 
financial  metrics  are  included  in  the  baseline  survey  and  management  information 
system (MIS) to be institutionalized. 
(ii)  Develop, maintain, and continuously update financial and disbursement projections for 
the JNNURM, based on approved CDPs and DPRs and progress reports from state and 
city governments. 
(iii)  Undertake  desk  appraisal  of  annual  statements/reports,  including  cash  utilization 
certificates  submitted  by  cities  accessing  JNNURM  grants,  and  check  them  for 
completeness and veracity.  
(iv)  Advise MUD leadership on financial management issues related to the JNNURM, and 
provide them with regular updates on the financial performance of the JNNURM. 
(v)  Identify  any  bottlenecks  in  the  performance  of  the  JNNURM  and  work  with  the 
consulting team and MUD to address any issues. 
(vi)  Evaluate, and assure quality of appraisals of CDPs and DPRs submitted for funding 
through the JNNURM.

Appendix 3  15
(vii)  Provide technical support to city and state governments to ensure that all interventions 
financed through the JNNURM are financially and/or economically viable. 
(viii)  Advise MUD and state and city governments on innovative financing and financial 
management strategies, where appropriate. 
(ix)  Assist the Directorate to review and consolidate JNNURM accounts. 
 
G.  Governance and Change Management Specialist (24 person-months) 
 
9.  The specialist should have (i) training in organizational behavior and management, and 
wide experience in governance reform, institutional development, and management of institutional 
change  processes;(ii)  at  least  7  years  experience  in  implementing  governance  reforms  in 
developing countries; and (iii) experience in providing/designing training inputs in the municipal 
environment. Previous experience in identifying/developing best practices will be an advantage. 
The specialist's primary responsibility will be to monitor, manage, and support governance reforms 
and change processes in JNNURM-funded cities and states to ensure successful implementation 
of the JNNURM. The specialist will also serve as the lead trainer in the technical assistance (TA) 
team,  and  be  responsible  for  identifying  regional  best  practices  in  urban  infrastructure 
development/management and institutional reform, and for ensuring their effective dissemination 
throughout JNNURM-supported cities/states. Specifically, the specialist will do the following: 
 
(i)  Support MUD in identifying and implementing governance reforms necessary at both 
central  and  state/ULB  levels  to  ensure  greater  transparency  and  efficiency  of  the 
JNNURM and its successful implementation. 
(ii)  Identify governance-related indicators to be included in the baseline survey, and tracked 
through the MIS to be developed through the TA. 
(iii)  Assist state and city governments in assessing their institutional conditions, and in 
developing their individual reform agendas for inclusion in the MOAs. 
(iv)  Assist the state and city governments in structuring and implementing effective and 
realistic change management processes, aimed at achieving the governance reforms 
included in the MOAs.  
(v)  Monitor progress and provide one-on-one support to cities and states, as required, to 
meet their institutional development targets. 
(vi)   Identify and document best practices in India relating to mandatory and obligatory 
reforms indicated in the JNNURM. In case suitable practices cannot be identified in 
India, regional best practices may be documented.  
(vii)  Disseminate best practices and other necessary training among city and state officials 
through  workshops,  training  sessions,  and  regional  Government  of  India  training 
centers. Develop training modules that can be used by regional trainers for JNNURM-
related programs.  
(viii)  Undertake a rapid training needs assessment of MUD officials and identify areas where 
capacity  strengthening  would  be  required.  Provided  training  for  designated  MUD 
officers and members of the project cell during the initial stages of the TA. 
(ix)  Assist the team leader in providing knowledge support as required.  
 
H.  Project Implementation Specialist (18 person-months) 
 
10.  The specialist will have an engineering, planning, or management background with at least 
7 years experience in monitoring and evaluating large development projects or programs. The 
specialist will be responsible for assuring quality and checking compliance of CDPs and DPRs, in 
collaboration with the municipal engineer, and for assisting state and city governments to ensure 
efficient implementation of project interventions. The implementation specialist will also work with 
the project monitoring and evaluation specialist to continuously assess progress on JNNURM-

16  Appendix 3 
 
funded interventions and provide any needed support to resolve bottlenecks. Specifically, the 
implementation specialist: 
 
(i)  Ensure quality and check compliance of CDPs and DPRs. 
(ii)  Monitor the status of reforms under the JNNURM at the city and state levels.  
(iii)  Monitor the status of implementation of JNNURM-funded project investments vis-à-vis 
approved timelines and key deliverables. 
(iv)  Develop quarterly aggregate reports on progress of reforms, financial disbursements, 
and other relevant indicators.  
(v)  Provide  technical  support  to  the  Mission  Directorate  in  evaluating  the  benefits  of 
JNNURM interventions, if required. 
(vi)  Work  with MUD,  the  team  leader,  and  other  experts  to  ensure  that  any  concerns 
identified are promptly addressed.  
(vii)  Provide other necessary support as identified by the team leader. 
 
I.  Legal and Regulatory Specialist (18 person-months) 
 
11.  The consultant should have at least 7 years experience in legislative and regulatory reforms 
in the government sector, preferably in the urban environment. Key inputs of this expert will include 
the following: 
 
(i)  Assess  the  MOAs,  CDPs,  and  DPRs  from  a  legal  perspective,  and  give 
recommendations on how to resolve any issues. 
(ii)  Provide necessary support in facilitating structuring reforms and simplifying legal and 
procedural frameworks at state and city levels where appropriate.  
(iii)  Support the training and change management specialist in developing reform agendas 
and strategies for JNNURM-funded cities and states.  
(iv)  Identify key bottlenecks in the regulatory environment related to JNNURM interventions 
and recommend how to resolve them. Reforms to be explored in detail include urban 
land ceilings, rent control, stamp duty, public disclosure, community participation, etc.  
(v)  Review  guidelines  and  documents  for  procurement,  contracting,  safeguards, 
compliance,  etc.  that  may  be  required  to  ensure  effective  implementation  of  the 
JNNURM. 
(vi)  Address any other legal matter relating to the JNNURM that may need to be addressed 
by the Directorate. 
(vii)  Provide other necessary support as identified by the team leader. 
 
J.  Urban Renewal Specialist (18 person-months) 
 
12.  The specialist should have a graduate degree in urban planning and/or conservation and at 
least  5  years  experience  in  urban  planning,  urban  renewal,  and  conservation  in  developing 
countries. Experience in renewal and redevelopment of inner city areas, housing development, and 
slum upgrading is required. Experience in integrated urban infrastructure master planning and 
other urban services is encouraged. The consultant is primarily responsible for (i) quality assurance 
of  redevelopment  plans  of  inner  city  areas,  development  proposals  of  heritage  areas,  and 
proposals  for  preservation  of  water  bodies;  and  (ii)  ensuring  that  all  project  investments  are 
considered  and  evaluated  in  the  context  of  the  broader  planning  requirements  of  each  city. 
Specifically, the specialist will do the following: 
 
(i)  Evaluate, ensure quality of,  and check all DPRs regarding redevelopment of inner city 
areas, development of heritage areas and preservation of water bodies; and  ensure full 
compliance  with  CDPs  and  all  JNNURM  planning  requirements,  as  well  as  other 
prevailing state and city planning documents.

Appendix 3  17
(ii)  Assist the team leader in developing guidelines for preparing, appraising, and evaluating 
CDPs and/or redevelopment plans of inner city areas, development proposals of heritage 
areas, and proposals for preservation of water bodies.   
(iii)  Provide technical support to state and city governments to ensure that the redevelopment 
of inner city areas, development of heritage areas, and preservation of water bodies are 
done in a comprehensive and meaningful manner as per the CDP and meet all JNNURM 
requirements. 
(iv)  Provide technical support to state or city government, wherever called for, in supporting 
implementation of mandatory and obligatory reforms including those related to building 
bylaws, redevelopment of inner city areas, development of heritage areas, preservation of 
water  bodies,  conservation  of  water,  and  streamlining  the  approval  process  for 
construction and/or redevelopment, etc.  
(v)  Support the team leader in undertaking workshops on implementation of mandatory and 
obligatory reforms for state and cities at the state capital. The focus will be on identifying 
road maps for implementing mandatory and obligatory reforms. 
(vi)  Provide other necessary support as identified by the team leader. 
 
K.  Economist (12 person-months) 
 
13.  The economist will have at least a master’s degree in economics and a minimum of 5 years 
experience in economic analysis of projects and governance programs. The expert must be able to 
demonstrate a solid understanding of economic principles and to advise MUD and state and ULB 
governments on strategies to maximize positive economic impacts through JNNURM interventions. 
Specifically, the economist will do the following: 
 
(i)  Work with the project monitoring and evaluation specialist to ensure that all important 
economic metrics are included in the baseline survey and MIS to be institutionalized. 
(ii)  Advise MUD leadership on economic and policy issues related to the JNNURM. 
(iii)  Ensure that CDP and DPR project appraisal guidelines include clear and transparent 
methodologies for assessing economic impact and viability of proposed projects. 
(iv)  Evaluate,  ensure  quality  of  appraisals  of  CDPs  and  DPRs  submitted  for  funding 
through the JNNURM. 
(v)  Provide  technical  support  to  city  and  state  governments  to  ensure  that  all 
interventions financed through the JNNURM are economically optimized and viable. 
(vi)  Advise  state  and  local  governments,  as  required,  on  strategies  to  prioritize 
investments included in CDPs in the basis of their economic impacts.  
 
L.  Transportation Planner (12 person-months) 
 
14.  The  consultant  will  have  university  degrees  in  transportation  planning  and  a  related 
engineering discipline, combined with at least 7 years experience in transportation planning and 
development. The consultant will be responsible for ensuring the quality of all DPR appraisals of 
transportation-related projects, and related CDPs as required. Previous experience with mass 
transit systems will be an advantage. Specifically, the consultant will do the following: 
 
(i)  Ensure that all CDPs effectively address issues of urban traffic and public transportation. 
(ii)  Assist in ensuring quality and monitoring compliance of DPRs related to traffic and 
transportation, and project implementation.  
(iii)  Wherever called for, provide technical support to cities in implementing transportation-
related projects funded through the JNNURM.  
(iv)  Provide other necessary support as identified by the team leader.

18  Appendix 3 
 
M.  Social Development Specialist (8 person-months) 
 
15.   The specialist will primarily assist the core team in ensuring that all CDPs and DPRs 
include adequate social safeguard measures, and respond to the needs of the poor. The specialist 
should  have  at  least  7  years  experience  in  undertaking  social  and  community  development 
initiatives and appraisals in the municipal environment, especially in relation to urban infrastructure 
projects. Specifically, the specialist will do the following: 
 
(i)  Ensure that social development indicators are part of the initial benchmarking survey 
and are monitored over time. 
(ii)  Ensure  all  CDPs  and  DPRs  submitted  to  MUD  have  been  developed  based  on 
principles of social inclusion, and that they address the needs of the poor.  
(iii)  Assess the social impacts of proposed projects, and monitor their impacts over time. 
(iv)  Assist and guide state and city governments on strategies to minimize any negative 
impacts,  and  ensure  full  compliance  with  Government  of  India  policies  related  to 
resettlement and social protection. 
(v)   Advise  MUD,  and  state  and  city  governments  on  reforms  related  to  community 
development including community participation law, earmarking of developed land for 
subsidized  housing  (wherever  applicable),  ensuring  adequate  earmarking  in  local 
government budgets for pro-poor development, etc.  
(vi)  Ensure that JNNURM-funded initiatives are planned and developed in a participatory 
manner.  
(vii)  Assist in establishing and institutionalizing systems of participatory decision making and 
information sharing in participating cities/ULBs. 
(viii)  Provide other necessary support as identified by the team leader. 
 
N.  Environment Specialist (8 person-months) 
 
16.   The specialist will have a university degree in environmental engineering or similar field 
and at least 5 years experience in assessing, monitoring, and mitigating environmental impacts of 
urban infrastructure investments. The consultant will primarily be responsible for ensuring quality 
on and checking compliance of CDPs and DPRs on environmental issues, and ensuring that 
negative environmental impacts of JNNURM- funded projects are minimized. The consultant will do 
the following: 
 
(i)  Ensure that environmental indicators are part of the initial baseline survey of JNNURM 
cities, and that such indicators are monitored over time. 
(ii)  Ensure all CDPs and DPRs submitted to MUD are environmentally sound, and that all 
efforts have been taken to minimize any negative impacts.  
(iii)  Assess the social impacts of proposed projects, and monitor their impacts over time. 
(iv)  In instances where negative impacts are expected, work closely with city and state 
governments, to ensure that all interventions are in full compliance with the Government 
and other acceptable guidelines. Ensure that all reasonable efforts to minimize negative 
impacts are taken. 
(v)  Provide other necessary support as identified by the team leader.
